awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Digital Mental Health for Children and Adolescents
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is improved children’s mental and behavioral health via the creation of a platform that unifies the silos of healthcare and education to put children and families first.  Due in part to the current pandemic, there is an increased need to support children’s mental and behavioral health.  The end-users are the 28 million children between 8-12 years old in America. The team is advancing patient-centered care and personalized education.  After the platform is tested for an initial age group of 8-12-year-olds, the plan is to expand the platform across the age-span, including early childhood through senior adults.  The platform promises engaging, self-contained, adaptable, safe, and research-based support and learning. The team expects to grow their market share through strategic partnerships with healthcare, education, industry, and non-profit partners. 
 
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project focuses on leveraging technology, including natural language processing, machine learning, and chatbots, to provide information to students, families, and educators about mental and behavioral health and to get feedback from these groups through their web-based computing devices. This project seeks to develop an online platform that will engage students and allow them to leverage personal care resources aimed at building resilience and providing them access to support and information customized to their individual needs. This Phase I project focuses on building a proof-of-concept platform that provides precision mental health solutions by combining interactive health and wellness methods with engaging content personalized and delivered by machine learning technologies and tools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Brav3Up is a content-driven mental health and wellness platform for youth and adolescents that can be accessed 24/7 from a desktop or mobile device. It provides timely, engaging research-based mental health and wellness content that is readily accessible to build happier and healthier youth.

We also support families and caregivers by providing content and care that addresses the specific needs of youth and adolescents. Brav3Up provides a full circle approach that offers the following capabilities:

  • prevention,by building healthy habits in youth
  • early intervention,by identifying patterns and giving youth support sooner so situations do not escalate, and
  • post-acute support by providing relevant, helpful content on the issues a youth is dealing with and giving them tools to help change patterns of behavior in the future.
  • Brav3Up?s custom-built recommendation engine allows youth who use theBrav3Up mobile app to access relevant, interesting, and effective content to
  • help support their mental health and wellness on both the Android and iPhone platforms. This mobile app includes the following interactive opportunities:
  • MyGives-service learning opportunities to create a sense of community & empowerment.
  • MyMissions-academic, behavioral, & health goals tracked and incentivized.
  • MyLife-youth-friendly content about life?s issues, such as getting along with siblings,coping with stress, dealing with bullying. MyLife also includes an online journaling option.
  • Champions-provides articles, podcasts, lessons and more to resource parents and educators as they support youth wellbeing.

The following table summarizes what we accomplished during NSF Phase 1 in the context of developing and evaluating our Brav3Up App and associated content in the context of our expected user community.

What We Did

What We Learned

Why It?s Important

208 Customer Discovery Interviews during Bootcamp & i-Corps

There is unquestionable market need and we have product-market fit

We have explored our ecosystem, substantiated the need for our product, and have begun conversations with potential partners, customers, and funders.

Analyzed, tagged, and reviewed our content for use in the platform

We have over 500 pieces of content, including articles, lessons, videos, songs, podcasts

We have conducted an extensive content analysis with our data team, as well as with a pediatrician and mental health professional to verify content quality and purpose.

Designed youth-focused and adult-focused user interfaces and user experiences

We must have unique engagement for both audience segments

We have created UI/UX that youth and adults want to use, which keeps them coming back to the platform.

Conducted focus groups on MVP

Youth and adults confirmed the need for our product offering and suggested ways to improve and grow the features

We have MVP feedback from all stakeholders to share with future partners

 


Last Modified: 07/17/2023
Modified by: Tamara Fyke
